722241f.text:
Park Avenue, north from 5lst Strcct, showing St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church (B.G. Goodhue, architect), east side frorn 50th to 51st Streets, built in 1918 on the site of F. & M.
Schaefer's Brewery.
Beyond the Hotel aabassador (1919), 51st to 52nd Streets, contiiuing up the east side, stand the Montana apartmients, built in 1912 on the site of the old Steinway Piano factory, from
52nd to 53rd Streets.
The little building on the N.E. corner of 53rd Street is one of the left-overs from the days before the railroad was electrified and the tracks covered over below 56th Street. A saloon used to occupy the parlor store. About 1925 it will give away to
a 15-story apartment building.
Note the little parks down the center of the avenue. They will be considerably narrowed in the alteration of 1927-28,
arain planted with grass and the public kept out.

722228f-b.text:
(1)
Park Avenue, north from 50th Street, showing the center parks as
they were from about 1917 to 1927.
In the foreground, the Hotel Ambassador on the N.E. corner of 5lst Street is shown. From 52nd to 53rd Streets on the east side stands the Montans, one of the earlier modern apartment buildings, erected 1913 on the site of the old Steinway Piano
Factory.
Careful scrutiny of the N.E. corner of 53rd Street will show that a sriall building has just been demolished; an apartment house is to be erected. On the west side from 52nd to 53rd Streets is the Racquet and Tennis Club, and above it a block of small
builcings dating back to the 188C's.
Summer 1924.
The New York Public Library has the negative of this picture
available for reproduction.
(2)
The same view, with camera a few feet farther north.
Summer 1924.
The New York Public Library has the negative of this picture
available for reproduction.

722230f-a.text:
Park Avenuc, east side, from 50th to 5lst Streets, showing St. Bartholomew's Church (Protestant Episcopal) and Potel Ambassador, both built 1918-19, on the site of the F & M. Schaefer brewery. Petween 52nd and 53rd Streets, the Montans apartments, built 1913 owwww
the site of the old Steinway fsctory.
Summer 1924.
.2--P.L. Sperr,Photogrwpher.  .. --~

722231f-a.text:
St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue, East Side, between E.50th to 51st Street, showing the beautiful window in the South Wall.
About 1930.
Boecher Ogden
Grand Central Terminal,
New York City

722233f-a.text:
(1)
Park Avenue, west side, from 50th to 5lst Streets. Over the excavation in the foreground will rise the new WaldorfAstoria.
March 4, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, showing more details of the Waldorf Astoria
block being prepared for foundations.
March 4, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, note railroad cars. This clearing uncovered part of the upper end of the Grand Central railroad yards; the cars in the foreground are directly underneath the site of the
old Adams Express buildings.
March 4, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

722235f-a.text:
(1)
Park Avenue, east side, from 50th to 5lst Streets, showing St. Bartholomew's Church on the southern side. To the east on 50th Street is part of the Roman Catholic Cathedral School (Bishop Hugghes Memorial). In the foreground construction is proceeding on the new Waldorf-Astoria in the block from 49th
to 50th Streets.
May 3, 1930.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
The same, showing the Ambassador Notel in the block north of the Church. Both Church and hotel were erected in 1918-19 on the site of the old F. & M. Schaefer brewery.
May 3, 1930.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722236f-a.text:
Park Ave., west side, north from East 50th to 53rd Streets.
May 3, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

722272f-a.text:
St. Bartholomew's Church Community House, on Park Avenue, showing the grilled work iron door. About 1930.

Beecher Ogden
Grand Central Terminal
New York City

722232f-a.text:
Park Avenue (foreground), east side, from E. 50th (right) to 51at (left) Streets, showing St. Bartholomew's P.E. Church and Community house occupying this frontage and being overshadowed by the G.E. (former R.C.A.) Building. To the right of the latter is the turreted roof of the Hotel Reverly as seen across the community house and R. C. Cathedral
High School.
1932.
wURNE BROTHERS.

722237f-a.text:
Park Avenue, south from 5lst Street and showing huildings south of 50th Street, on a fine spring morning shortly after the returh of lemel
beer.
Note the cozy, enclosed feeling given by the surrounding buildings, which
form a sort of hox canyon.
On the left is the new Wheldorf-Astoria, with its flags out. The picture ives P fine view of the Neu. York Central building, which
cuts off the Avenue at 48th Street.
May 15, 1933.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.

722234f-a.text:
Park Ave., east side, from East 50th to 51st Streets.  Shown is St. Bartholomew's P.E. Church, organized in 1835. This congregation worship.ed for many years in a church in pafayette Place. A new church was erected in 1876 on Madison Ave., at the S.W. corner of East 44th Strcet. This present edifice being built in 1918-1919, on the site of the old F & M Schaefer Brewery. At the rear of the church appears a portion of the General Electric
Puilding (570 Lexington Ave).
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

1509379-a.title: 50th Street (East) - Park Avenue - Lexington Avenue
1509379-a.folder: 50th Street (East) - Park Avenue - Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, NY

1508017-a.title: Park Avenue - 50th Street - 51st Street, east side
1508017-a.folder: Park Avenue - 50th Street - 51st Street, east side, Manhattan, NY

722229f-a.text:
(1)
St. Bartholomew's Church (Protestant Episcopal), erected 1918-19 on the site of the old F. & M. Schaefer brewery, Park Avenue, east side, between 50th and 5lst Streets. The architect was
Bertram G. Goodhue.
September 2, 1928.
P. L. Sgerr.
(2)
Another view, two years later, when construction had begun on the new Waldorf-Astoria in the block to the south of the church.
May 3, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, in another two years, after the erection of the R. C. A. Building (later to be called the General Electric Building) on the S.W. corner of Lexington Avenue and 5lat Street.
July 24, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
